thread.title: Min.: Universities' firm commitment to promoting sustainable and comprehensive development-SIS
thread.title_full: Min.: Universities' firm commitment to promoting sustainable and comprehensive development-SIS

title: Min.: Universities' firm commitment to promoting sustainable and comprehensive development-SIS
text: Media Center Min.: Universities' firm commitment to promoting sustainable and comprehensive development Thursday، 18 July 2024 - 09:01 PM The Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research, Dr. Ayman Ashour, emphasized the unwavering commitment of universities to promoting sustainable and comprehensive development across the Republic. He commended the efforts of the 27 public universities and Al-Azhar University in enhancing the quality of life for Egyptian citizens. The Minister stressed the Ministry’s keenness on the participation of universities in the presidential initiative “Decent Life” to cooperate in developing society and raising the quality of life, pointing to the continuation of work to activate the role of universities and higher education institutions in serving the surrounding environment, and achieving integration between academic, industrial and service institutions in facing the challenges of economic and societal development. He referred to the protocol signed between the Supreme Council of Universities and the “Decent Life” Foundation. With the aim of raising the educational, health, economic and social level of the most needy families across Egypt, alleviating the burden on citizens, increasing the number of medical, veterinary and agricultural convoys, and providing awareness and educational services on various social and health issues for citizens. The Minister explained that Egyptian universities launched 535 medical convoys, and the number of cases benefiting from them reached 303,469 beneficiaries. Also, 1,025 convoys were launched in cooperation with the presidential initiative “Decent Life,” and the number of beneficiaries from them reached 461,029 beneficiaries, bringing the total number of beneficiaries from the medical convoys to 719,498 citizens.
